free_text.Content: [li] Overview of forest management in function of the tree species and concept of sustainable development (specific to forestry and in the actual broad sense)[br/][li] Biology of wood formation[br/][li] Physiology and Chemistry of wood[br/][li] Microscopic and macroscopic structures of the main softwood and hardwood species (identification tests)[br/][li] Biological, physical and mechanical prop. of woods[br/][li] Forms of uses in function to the properties[br/][li] Modern wood-based materials and their applications[br/][li] Life cycle assessments and potentials for sustainability.
free_text.Type of teaching: Frontal and student-centered t., insight in laboratory work, student presentations
free_text.Learning outcomes: [li] Elaborating a general comprehension of the biological processes leading to the formation of wood structures (for conifers and broadleaved, temperate and tropical species)[br/][li] Identifying the main species using their macroscopic features [br/][li] Understanding the relationships between these structures and the specific properties and quality parameters of wood as a material [br/][li] Differentiating the forms of effective uses and deducing further potentials[br/][li] Presenting a tree species, its wood and some specific uses[br/][li] Getting an overview of the different modern wood-based materials and their fields of application [br/][li] Putting the technical timber utilization in relation to the modern concept of sustainable development.[br/]
